messages.text:
Hmm. I'm not a huge fan. I'd prefer something like PATHSolver.jl.

That being said, it's your package, so if you really want to keep this name, ping me in 3 days and I can merge it.

But I would recommend at least considering something more descriptive, like PATHSolver.jl.

elements.text: Hmm. I'm not a huge fan. I'd prefer something like PATHSolver.jl.
That being said, it's your package, so if you really want to keep this name, ping me in 3 days and I can merge it.
But I would recommend at least considering something more descriptive, like PATHSolver.jl.

messages.text:
I registered a package 6 hours ago (automerged), and when I run the `Pkg.add` command, still the previous version is added. How can I fix this?
<https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/issues/28687>

I was told that "It takes some time for it to propagate to the servers.". How long exactly does it take for the package to arrive to my place?

messages.text: Usually not this long so perhaps something is stuck.

> A patch release is not allowed to narrow the supported ranges of Julia versions. The ranges have changed from Pkg.Types.VersionRange[VersionRange("1.5")] (in 4.8.3) to Pkg.Types.VersionRange[VersionRange("1.5.0-1")] (in 4.8.4).
am I missing something or the new range of versions is _larger_ than the old one? :thinking_face:

messages.text: Hi everyone! Could someone please have a look at a new package registration for KROME.jl? <https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/29997|https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/29997>? It seems to be blocked due to naming similarities, but since the package is a wrapper for the KROME library (<http://kromepackage.org/|http://kromepackage.org/>) I feel like it should really be named after it.

elements.text: Hi everyone! Could someone please have a look at a new package registration for KROME.jl?
https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/29997
? It seems to be blocked due to naming similarities, but since the package is a wrapper for the KROME library (
http://kromepackage.org/
) I feel like it should really be named after it.

messages.text: I’m working on an automerge guideline for RegistryCI to check if the package has an OSI-approved license. Sometimes license files contain more than one license, for example in my package there are two MIT licenses, since some of the code is derived from another package: <https://github.com/ericphanson/GuessworkQuantumSideInfo.jl/blob/master/LICENSE>. In the case that we find more than 1 license in the license file, should we require *all* the licenses found are OSI approved, or just that one of them is? or just that the first one is?

elements.text: I’m working on an automerge guideline for RegistryCI to check if the package has an OSI-approved license. Sometimes license files contain more than one license, for example in my package there are two MIT licenses, since some of the code is derived from another package:
. In the case that we find more than 1 license in the license file, should we require
all
the licenses found are OSI approved, or just that one of them is? or just that the first one is?

for m in split("PrettyPrint ChainRules GridVisualize OptionalArgChecks ProximalAlgorithms Matcha Plots RBNF AdvancedHMC SymEngine StaticArrays  GaussianProcesses KrigingModel RecipesBase");
       mktempdir() do d; Pkg.activate(d) do; Pkg.add(m); end; end; end

messages.text: That's a bit of a weak point with Pkg right now. They get installed when the tests are run but that temp manifest gets removed after the tests. We should restructure things so it can be kept around.

elements.text: That's a bit of a weak point with Pkg right now. They get installed when the tests are run but that temp manifest gets removed after the tests. We should restructure things so it can be kept around.

messages.text: Heads up: I'm going to send out some test balloons (probably two) to verify that the dependency confusion detection in AutoMerge is effective. Should happen within the next couple of hours.

messages.text: I'm working on an experimental package that may ultimately be absorbed into another package. Is that a good reason to not register it? Are outdated packages ever removed from the registry? I'd like to avoid potentially confusing users if there are two packages with similar names but one is discontinued.

elements.text: I'm working on an experimental package that may ultimately be absorbed into another package. Is that a good reason to not register it? Are outdated packages ever removed from the registry? I'd like to avoid potentially confusing users if there are two packages with similar names but one is discontinued.

messages.text:
> Are outdated packages ever removed from the registry?
I think not

elements.text: Are outdated packages ever removed from the registry?
I think not

messages.text: Removing packages could break working code, so that’s a no-no

elements.text: Removing packages could break working code, so that’s a no-no

messages.text: We have in the past removed packages

elements.text: We have in the past removed packages

messages.text: I believe at one point Stefan removed packages that didn't work on 1.0

elements.text: I believe at one point Stefan removed packages that didn't work on 1.0

messages.text: Yep that was very early on and was reasonable in that case, but removing a package because it was discontinued would break any code that isn't/won't be updated to use its successor. That can happen in corporate environments where the versions of things need to remain stable and particular.

elements.text: Yep that was very early on and was reasonable in that case, but removing a package because it was discontinued would break any code that isn't/won't be updated to use its successor. That can happen in corporate environments where the versions of things need to remain stable and particular.

messages.text:
While things are never and will never (exceptions aside) be deleted from registry at some point we might have the option to `unlist` them s that they don’t tab-complete, and maybe don’t block the name from being used for something else, and maybe show a warning on install.

<https://github.com/JuliaLang/Pkg.jl/issues/2194>

root.text: I'm working on an experimental package that may ultimately be absorbed into another package. Is that a good reason to not register it? Are outdated packages ever removed from the registry? I'd like to avoid potentially confusing users if there are two packages with similar names but one is discontinued.

elements.text: I'm working on an experimental package that may ultimately be absorbed into another package. Is that a good reason to not register it? Are outdated packages ever removed from the registry? I'd like to avoid potentially confusing users if there are two packages with similar names but one is discontinued.
While things are never and will never (exceptions aside) be deleted from registry at some point we might have the option to
unlist
them s that they don’t tab-complete, and maybe don’t block the name from being used for something else, and maybe show a warning on install.

messages.text: the automerge name similarity check has been in place for ~4 months now; any feedback or changes we should make? the initial cutoffs were fairly arbitrary, do they seem too high or low? is the messaging clear in the comment?
